Accessibility.html:
General

When implementing the Avatar component, itâ€™s important to keep several ideas in mind:
Non-text content needs alt tagsâ€¨Since there are no labels used for avatars, make sure that avatars are implemented with appropriate alternative text. WCAG 1.1.1, 1.3.1
Make sure itâ€™s built as a button, if itâ€™s used as a buttonâ€¨Avatars are typically not interactive. Using the avatar as a link or button can be problematic for users of assistive technologies like screen readers, because there is no text label indicating that it is a button or what it does when clicked. WCAG 2.4.4, 2.4.6
Make sure thatâ€™s itâ€™s built as a button when itâ€™s used as a button.
Focus Visibilityâ€¨The keyboard should be able to navigate to it (if it is a button). WCAG 2.4.7

Interaction Guidance

Include some general information about the interactive elements of the component. Note any important guidance on accessibility.

Check out the Accessibility Guidelines put together by the Control Hub Team for more insight.

Guidelines.html:
Overview

Avatars are visual representations of users that leverage images, icons, or text. They also can contain a presence indicator which shows the userâ€™s status on the product.

Use Cases

Avatars can be used in a variety of settings, such as profile pages, user settings, or in a list view.

When to Use

Displaying a user's profile image or initials in a user profile, comments section, or messaging application.
Displaying the profile image or initials of a group or team in a project management application or collaboration tool.

When to Use

Displaying images or icons that are not related to user profiles or identities.
Using the Avatar component to display images or icons that are too small to be recognizable.

Anatomy

Types

There are four different types of Avatars:
Photo
Text
Icon
Multiuser; cannot have presence.

Text, icon, and multiuser background colors

Designers should feel free to change the background color of the Text, Icon, and Multiuser Avatars, wit our theme tokens. â€¨â€¨However, do not change the text or icon color of the component.

Behavior

Avatars can be either static, or interactive elements. If interactive, they will behave like buttons.

Checkboxes under page header

Presenceâ€¨Avatars can indicate presence to users. We have several options for presence:
No presenceâ€¨This indicates that the user has no presence.
Activeâ€¨This indicates that the represented user is present on the product.
Away

Do not disturbâ€¨This indicates that the user represented has set their account to â€œdo not disturb.â€
Quiet hoursâ€¨This indicates that the user has their account set to â€œquiet hours.â€
Inactive

Multiuser Avatars

For an avatar that represents multiple users, we use numbers. At more than 99 users, we use â€œ99+â€ to indicate that it is more than 99 users.

Doâ€™s and Dontâ€™s

Checkbox Text Wrap Alignment

Do change text, icon, and multiuser backgrounds with the appropriate common tokens if your design requires it.

Do not change text or icons within the avatar.
